Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Time-Consistent Risk-Averse Control of Markov Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ruszczynski, 1312016
Dentcheva, 1311978

The project is concerned with optimal control of multi-dimensional dynamic stochastic systems with risk aversion. Two approaches to risk aversion are considered: dynamic risk measures and stochastic orders. The investigators seek to advance their work on risk-averse discrete-time models and to develop general methodology for incorporating risk models into continuous-time optimal control problems of Markov structure. Three major challenges are associated with this project. First, the investigators develop proper mathematical tools for measuring risk in a time-consistent manner that would be suitable for continuous-time Markov systems. Second, the investigators develop optimality theory for control problems involving time-consistent dynamic models of risk. This includes the analysis of the structure of the control models, existence of solutions, and properties of the solutions. When developing risk-averse control models the third challenge has to be taken into account: the possibility to solve the problems numerically in an efficient way.

Decision and control problems under uncertainty arise in many areas: energy production and distribution, telecommunication, insurance and finance, logistics, medicine, security and military applications. In most cases decisions have to be made over time: decisions, as well as the random environment, influence evolution of a system, which creates the need to make new decisions, etc. Therefore, a policy has to be designed that incorporates rules for responding to future states of the system. So far, most theoretical models of such control processes have been based on average performance criteria. The investigators propose to take into account risk, that is, the possibility of occurrence of highly undesirable scenarios. The project develops mathematical models for quantifying risk in dynamical systems that evolve in a continuous way. It also provides methods to determine the best policy, when risk aversion is essential.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. The main outcome of our collaborative research with Andrzej Ruszczynski is the development of a time-consistent risk measurement for continuous time Markov processes, where the state space is discrete.  Our analysis is based on dual representation of coherent risk measures, differentiability concepts for multivalued mappings, and a refined concept of time consistency. We have formulated the concepts of weak and strong time consistency, which refine the concept introduced earlier and facilitate the goal of measuring rik in continuous time. 

We prove that the risk measures are defined by a family of risk evaluation functionals (transition risk mappings), which depend on state, time, and the transition function. Their dual representations are risk multikernels of the Markov system.We introduce the concept of a semi-derivative of a risk multikernel and use it to generalize the concept of a generator of a Markov process. Using those semi-derivatives, we derive a system of ordinary differential equations that the risk evaluation must satisfy. Those equations generalize the classical backward Kolmogorov equations for Markov processes to more general structures of the cost process and to the risk evaluation (rather than to the average performance).

Another outcome is the construction of discrete-time approximations to the continuous-time risk measures which converge when the time-interval decreases to zero.

A paper contaning these results is currently under review in SIAM J. Financial Mathematics.

Our current work aims at addressing risk-averse optimal control for continuous time Markov decision problems with discrete state-space. 

2. In a joint work with my graduate student Eli Wolfhagen, we have introduced a new two-stage optimization model with a look-ahead time-period and risk-control of a multivariate performance criterion on the future time-period. This structure is a building block of a dynamic programming problem and frequently used for look-ahead policies in approximate dynamic programming. 

Additionally, to the work on the model done in the previous period, we have incorporated novel combinatorial techniques for testing the stochastic order relation for the multivariate performance criterion and have analysed its convergence. 

More advanced numerical approach to risk-averse optimization with order constraints was developed in a joint work with Eli Wolfhagen and Dr. Gabriela Martinez, currenly working at Mayo Clinic. The appraoch is based on augmented Lagrangian framework. We have presented several algorithms for solving stochastic optimization problems with univariate and multivariate stochastic order constraints.

Two additional papers on this topic were published in this period of the project: one in Mathematics of Operations Research and one in Operation Research. Additionally, we have presented the results at several scientific meetings.

3. In a joint work with my graduate student, Constantine A. Vitt, we consider problems of  machine learning and propose risk-averse point of view. We have developed a new approach to robust classification, accounting for changes of the decision-maker's attitude to misclassification errors. We develop risk-sharing ideas, which go beyond the available literature on risk-sharing in finance as the latter are inapplicable to the problems at hand. We have extended the numerical study from SVM to multi-class classification and have expored varios risk-averse approaches.

This work is persented in two papers: one is under a second review, and another one is nearly ready for submission. The student has presented the research at two scientific meetings.

4. In a joint work with Andrzej Ruszczynski and a graduate student, Curtis McGinity, we have initiated research in risk-averse design of clinical trials. 

We have proposed several risk-averse policies in the framework of approximate dynamic programming. We have identified appropriate features and have tested numerically the performace of the new approach. The effect of using coherent measures of risk is substantial; it leads to better, much focused distribution of the medical dose recommendation. 

A research paper with the results in process of preparation.
